options: B. Is planar, cyclic, conjugated with 4n+2 π electrons
C. Has alternating single and double bonds
questions.explanation: Hückel's rule: aromatic compounds are cyclic, planar, fully conjugated, with 4n+2 π electrons. Benzene has 6 (n=1).
EAS substitutes an H for an electrophile, maintaining the aromatic system. Addition would destroy aromaticity.

questions.question_text: In bromination of benzene, the catalyst FeBr3 functions to:
questions.explanation: FeBr3 (Lewis acid) polarizes Br2, generating electrophilic Br+ that attacks the π system.
EDGs and halogens direct to ortho/para positions. EDGs donate electrons, stabilizing carbocation at ortho/para. Halogens are exceptions (deactivating but o/p directing).
EWGs withdraw electrons by resonance from ortho/para positions, making meta relatively favored.
Friedel-Crafts alkylation: alkyl halide + Lewis acid catalyst introduces alkyl group onto benzene.
Friedel-Crafts acylation uses acyl chloride + Lewis acid to introduce acyl group. No rearrangement unlike alkylation.
Mixed acid (HNO3 + H2SO4) generates nitronium ion (NO2+), the electrophile for nitration.
Sulfonation (H2SO4/SO3) is reversible. Heating with dilute H2SO4 removes SO3H. Useful for blocking positions.
Activating groups (EDGs like -OH, -NH2, -alkyl) increase electron density, making the ring more nucleophilic toward electrophiles.
Deactivating groups (EWGs like -NO2, -CF3, -COR) decrease electron density, making the ring less reactive toward electrophiles.
Halogens withdraw electrons inductively (deactivating) but donate by resonance to ortho/para (directing). Unique exception.

questions.question_text: Aniline (C6H5NH2) is a stronger ortho/para director than benzene because:
options: B. Lone pair on N donates into ring by resonance
questions.explanation: The nitrogen lone pair donates electrons into the ring by resonance, strongly activating ortho and para positions.
FC reactions fail with strongly deactivated rings (nitro, multiple halogens) because the ring is too electron-poor to attack the electrophile.

questions.question_text: The arenium ion (sigma complex) in EAS is:
questions.explanation: Arenium ion is the cationic intermediate after electrophile attack. It's resonance-stabilized but non-aromatic. Loss of H+ restores aromaticity.

questions.question_text: Phenol (C6H5OH) is more acidic than alcohols because:
questions.explanation: Phenoxide ion is resonance-stabilized—the negative charge is delocalized into the benzene ring, stabilizing the conjugate base.

options: B. Resonance with the benzene ring
questions.explanation: Benzyl carbocation (PhCH2+) is stabilized by resonance—the positive charge is delocalized into the benzene ring.
Birch reduction (Na/Li in NH3 with alcohol) partially reduces benzene to 1,4-cyclohexadiene, not complete reduction.

options: B. Electron-poor ring with good leaving group
questions.explanation: NAS requires electron-withdrawing groups (especially ortho/para to leaving group) to stabilize the anionic Meisenheimer complex.
Heterocyclic aromatics contain non-carbon atoms in the ring: pyridine (N), pyrrole (N), furan (O), thiophene (S).
Pyridine is aromatic with 6 π electrons. The nitrogen lone pair is in an sp² orbital perpendicular to the ring, not part of aromaticity.

questions.question_text: Pyrrole is more reactive than benzene because:
options: B. N lone pair donates into the ring
C. It has less π electrons
questions.explanation: In pyrrole, the N lone pair is part of the aromatic system (6 π electrons total), making the ring electron-rich and more reactive.
Naphthalene (two fused benzene rings) has 10 π electrons (4n+2, n=2), making it aromatic.

questions.question_text: Side chain oxidation of alkylbenzenes gives:
questions.explanation: Strong oxidation (KMnO4, hot) of any alkyl substituent gives benzoic acid—benzene ring is resistant to oxidation.
Reduction of nitrobenzene (H2/Pd, or Fe/HCl, or Sn/HCl) gives aniline (aminobenzene).
Clemmensen reduction (Zn-Hg/HCl) reduces carbonyl to CH2, useful after Friedel-Crafts acylation to get alkylbenzene without rearrangement.

options: B. Hydrazine and base with heat
questions.explanation: Wolff-Kishner (NH2NH2, KOH, heat) reduces C=O to CH2 under basic conditions. Clemmensen uses acidic conditions.
Diazotization: aniline + NaNO2 + HCl at 0°C gives diazonium salt, a versatile intermediate for synthesis.

questions.question_text: Diazonium salts can be converted to which product with CuCN?
questions.explanation: Sandmeyer reactions: ArN2+ with CuCN gives ArCN. CuCl gives ArCl. CuBr gives ArBr. Very useful for synthesis.
Cyclic, planar, conjugated systems with 4n π electrons are antiaromatic—destabilized relative to open-chain analogs.

options: B. It has 6 π electrons (4n+2, n=1)
questions.explanation: Cyclopentadienyl anion has 6 π electrons (5 from ring, 1 from negative charge = 6 total), satisfying Hückel's rule.

options: B. It has 6 π electrons (cycloheptatrienyl cation)
questions.explanation: Tropylium cation: 7-membered ring with 6 π electrons (positive charge removes one electron), making it aromatic.
Gattermann-Koch reaction (CO + HCl + AlCl3) formylates benzene, adding CHO group.

questions.question_text: The intermediate in EAS is stabilized best when the substituent is:
options: B. Ortho or para to positive charge for EDGs
questions.explanation: EDGs stabilize arenium ion best when attack is ortho/para because the substituent can donate electrons directly to the positive carbon.
Phenyl (Ph) is the C6H5- group (benzene minus one H). Benzyl is C6H5CH2-. Benzoyl is C6H5CO-.
Benzoyl is the acyl group C6H5CO-, derived from benzoic acid. Used in Friedel-Crafts acylation.

options: B. Substitution at the carbon bearing the substituent
questions.explanation: Ipso substitution occurs at the carbon already bearing a substituent, displacing that group.
Catechol is ortho-dihydroxybenzene (1,2). Resorcinol is meta (1,3). Hydroquinone is para (1,4).

questions.question_text: Toluene is more reactive than benzene in EAS because:
options: B. CH3 donates electrons by hyperconjugation
questions.explanation: Methyl group is weakly electron-donating through hyperconjugation, activating the ring for electrophilic attack.

questions.question_text: The rate-determining step in EAS is:
options: B. Formation of arenium ion (electrophile attack)
questions.explanation: Formation of arenium ion by electrophile attack on the ring is the slow, rate-determining step. Loss of H+ is fast.
OCH3 donates electrons by resonance, strongly activating the ring and directing to ortho/para positions.
CHO group is electron-withdrawing (carbonyl), deactivating the ring and directing to meta position.
Alkylate first (methyl is o/p-directing, activating). Then nitrate to get para product. Nitro group is deactivating—would block alkylation.

questions.question_text: Carbocation rearrangement is a problem in:
questions.explanation: FC alkylation can give rearranged products (hydride/methyl shifts to more stable carbocation). Acylation avoids this—acylium ion doesn't rearrange.

options: B. A highly reactive triple bond in benzene ring
questions.explanation: Benzyne is a highly reactive intermediate with a formal triple bond in a 6-membered ring. Forms in elimination-addition mechanism.
PAHs have multiple fused benzene rings (naphthalene, anthracene, phenanthrene). Some are carcinogenic due to metabolic activation.

questions.question_text: Resonance energy of benzene is approximately:
questions.explanation: Resonance energy (~36 kcal/mol) is the extra stability of benzene compared to hypothetical cyclohexatriene, measured by heat of hydrogenation.

questions.question_text: Halogenation of benzene requires catalyst because:
options: B. Benzene is too stable; catalyst generates stronger electrophile
questions.explanation: Benzene's stability (aromaticity) makes it unreactive toward weak electrophiles. Lewis acid generates more reactive E+ species.

questions.question_text: Which is the strongest activating group?
questions.explanation: NH2 is the strongest activator (lone pair donation). Order: -NH2 > -OH > -OR > -alkyl. Halogens are deactivating.

options: B. Coupling of diazonium salts with activated aromatics
questions.explanation: Diazonium salts couple with electron-rich aromatics (phenols, anilines) to form colored azo compounds (-N=N-) used as dyes.
